content: In the Air Force, you get screwed up in training, they don't recycle you, they wash you out. It's that simple. There are so many people trying to get slots, and so many slots are being reduced that the competition is murder. You bring him home on anything short or a major emergency, he may not have a place to go back to... there won't be any room in the next class. That thing will be booked clear full, as will the next - - You may just have to have mom and dad do the hand-holding on this one - - Wandering and Wondering

content: There is no complications and your spouse is in the middle of training, unless it is an option and allowed by the CO to miss class on Friday and fly back Sunday it will not happen. The military will also NOT pay for him to come home so it would out of your own pocket. The CO can refuse because it isn't possible and this can mean a delay in his training. Children are born whether or not the father is there. And actually up until about 30 years ago if that, most fathers weren't allowed to be there, they pacing outside in the hall or were at work, or a bar or who know where. The doctor can fax the information but no guarantees. It will not be the first thing he misses for the child being in the military. He can miss the first words, first steps, first Christmas, first day in Kindergarten, first soccer day, and the list continues. It sucks but it is part of military life.

content: The Red Cross is there to get your soldier/airman/whatever home during an emergency (i.e. his or your father or mother die, bad car accident and you and the kids are in the hospital, etc) unless there are serious complications with your pregnancy, they won't send him home and even if there were, the baby would be born and everything over before he got there any way. Let him stay in training. When he finishes that, he may have a little more le-way to get some time off. And Navywife is totally right, he'll wind up missing more than seems fair... but you both made the decision to have a child while he was in the military. You should definitely get accustomed to your needs/wants/desires coming second to the Military... after all, when he signed the line, you became the Mistress

content: Looks to me like the original poster has RTBd, but I'll throw in one example I know of personally about how the Air Force handles interruptions in training: When I was at one of several Weapons Controller Schools I attended, there was this young 2nd Lt. who was doing an acceptable job. One day, one of the instructors comes in looking for the "Grey-headed 1st Lt..." (me) with the opportunity of a life time: One of the F-4s going up for intercepts that day had a bad targeting radar, so the WIZO was staying on the ground. That meant a chance for someone to ride in the back seat! I thought about it, but over 40, I didn't need a thrill ride, so I passed. This young 2nd Lt. jumped on the opportunity!! Well, I was controlling the F-4s, snapping them all over the sky, and the young man got really air sick. In fact, he got so bad that he couldn't drive back to the billets, so I took him - and every time I stopped or made a turn, he had to get out and throw up - -!! Well, he tried to come back to training the next day, but when he looked at that green strobe going around the scope, he would get dizzy and have to run for it... He eventually missed 3 days of training in a row, and could not pass the End of Phase Test for that week of training - - They gave him a Re-Take the next day, which he also failed - and they washed him out and sent him home!! Just like that!! Gone...! Pretty typical of all the Courses and Schools I've done in the Air Force - no recycle and no sympathy - - - Wandering and Wondering
